original_question: Is it fair that my friend never shares snacks with anyone?

lesson.subject: philosophy_core
lesson.title: Ethics Seeds: Fairness, Promises, and Honesty
lesson.description: An early ethics lane that helps you notice fairness and harm, why promises and honesty matter, and how kindness and responsibility affect other people.

content.spine_position: Begins in Kâ??8 as feelings about fair vs unfair, hurt vs help, and keeping promises; becomes structured normative ethics in high school and undergrad (consequences, rules, virtues, care); and deepens into metaethics and applied ethics at grad level.
prepares_for: Applied ethics (digital life, AI, environment, health).
kid_core_explanations: Fairness is about treating people in a way that makes sense and does not leave someone hurt for no good reason.
Harm is when someone gets hurt in their body or feelings; help is when we make things better or kinder for them.
A promise is when you tell someone you will do something. Being honest means telling the truth and trying to do what you said.
key_concepts: Fair vs unfair in sharing, turn-taking, and rules.
Harm vs help: how actions affect others, not just yourself.
Promises and trust: people rely on what you say.
Honesty as more than 'not lying'â??also owning up to mistakes.
Kindness and responsibility as everyday ways to care.

micro_stories.name: sharing_snacks
micro_stories.story: Three friends bring snacks to share. Two of them give snacks to everyone, but one keeps all of theirs and says, 'Itâ??s mine, I donâ??t have to share.'
questions: Does this feel fair or unfair? Why?
How might the other friends feel?
What could the friend do differently to be more fair or kind?

micro_stories.name: test_answer
micro_stories.story: You see a classmate looking at someone elseâ??s paper during a test. They later say, 'Itâ??s not a big deal, everyone cheats sometimes.'
questions: Is 'everyone does it' a good reason here?
Who could be harmed by this choice?
What would an honest and fair choice look like in this situation?

micro_stories.name: broken_promise
micro_stories.story: You promised a friend you would help them with a project after school, but when the time comes you decide to play a game instead and never tell them.
questions: How might your friend feel when you do not show up?
Does breaking this promise affect how much they trust you?
What could you do or say to repair the situation?

guided_questions: Think of a time something felt unfair to you. What happened, and why did it feel unfair?
Think of a time you kept a promise, even when it was hard. How did that feel afterward?
When you tell the truth about a mistake, what happens to trust between you and other people?

silent_questions: Who is helped and who is hurt in this story?
What promises or expectations are in the background here?
Is the child focusing only on rules, only on feelings, or on both?
pattern_labels: Appeal to 'everyone does it' as a weak reason.
Special obligations to friends, family, or teammates.

moves: Ask the child what matters most to them in the story.
Reflect their answer in simple language to show understanding.
Offer gentle questions instead of harsh judgments.
templates: It sounds like this felt {emotion} for you. What part made it feel that way?
If you imagine being the other person in the story, how might it feel?

reflection_prompts: Today, notice one small choice where you could either help or harm someoneâ??s feelings. What did you choose, and why?
Think of one promise you want to keep this week. What can you do to make it easier to keep that promise?
content.next_suggestion: Next, you can explore simple digital-life dilemmasâ??like sharing passwords, posting pictures, or including others in group chatsâ??and ask what is fair and kind there.

practice.story: Three friends bring snacks to share. Two of them give snacks to everyone, but one keeps all of theirs and says, 'Itâ??s mine, I donâ??t have to share.'
practice.child_answer: Is it fair that my friend never shares snacks with anyone?
practice.prime_paraphrase: You said: Is it fair that my friend never shares snacks with anyone?
practice.prime_feedback: You are noticing how sharing (or not sharing) affects everyone. When one friend keeps everything, others may feel left out or hurt. Fairness here is not always 'exactly equal', but it does notice how people feel.
practice.follow_up_question: If you were the friend with extra snacks, what could you do to make this feel more fair or kind?
